column2:
COVID-19 negative certification subject to special conditions. 1. All travellers must complete the Passenger Declaration Form.
2. All travellers must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result. Details in the sections below.
3. From 1 February, the vaccination certificate is valid for 270 days (9 months). For persons who receive their booster dose, the certificate is valid for 1 year.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to category.
Government shortens quarantine period to 7 days for some travelers. Returning travelers, as well as nationals of other countries, will no longer be required to stay self-isolated for ten days as the quarantine period has been shortened. (SVI, 12.01.2022)
An updated list of countries for which entry to Estonia is subject to limitations is available on the Estonian Ministry of Foreign Affairs website.
- Travellers on the green list enjoy no restrictions on movement.
- Travellers on the yellow list must present proof of vaccination and a negative test result. PCR tests must be taken within 72 hours of arrival and antigen tests within 48 hours. Travellers without a negative test certificate can take a test on arrival and quarantine while awaiting the results.
- Unvaccinated travellers on the red list must quarantine for 10 days on arrival. Tests must be taken on arrival and on day six. If both tests are negative, quarantine can be shortened. Vaccinated travellers are not required to test.
- Travellers fromomicron-risk countries must isolate for 10 days on arrival. Their status will also be affected by their vaccination status and willingness to undergo further tests.
Children below 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.

column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU:

Documents equivalent to the 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) are also accepted, if they meet the same requirements lised above for the EUDCC.

All travellers must complete the Passenger Declaration Form and provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result.

Learn More:

Visit Estonia

______________________

You can find the latest information on air travel regulations for this country on the IATA website.

You can also find information about your passenger rights on our portal for citizens.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



*Transit:

As a general rule, passengers in transit in the EU+ area are exempted from temporary travel restrictions.

EU citizens entering the EU from a third country, as well as their family members, irrespective of their nationality, are exempted from the travel restrictions regardless of whether or not they are returning to their country of nationality or residence.

Passengers travelling from a non-EU country to another non-EU country may transit through the international transit area of airports located in the Schengen area. Rules regarding airport transit visa requirements continue to apply.



*From Third Countries:

All travellers must complete the Passenger Declaration Form and provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result.

  • From 1 February, the vaccination certificate is valid for 270 days (9 months). For persons who receive their booster dose, the certificate is valid for 1 year.
  • Travellers on the green list enjoy no restrictions on movement.
  • Travellers on the yellow list must present proof of vaccination and a negative test result. PCR tests must be taken within 72 hours of arrival and antigen tests within 48 hours. Travellers without a negative test certificate can take a test on arrival and quarantine while awaiting the results.
  • Unvaccinated travellers on the red list must quarantine for 10 days on arrival. Tests must be taken on arrival and on day six. If both tests are negative, quarantine can be shortened. Vaccinated travellers are not required to test.
  • Travellers from omicron-risk countries must isolate for 10 days on arrival. Their status will also be affected by their vaccination status and willingness to undergo further tests.

Children below 12 years are exempt from quarantine and testing requirements.

______________________

You can find the latest information on air travel regulations for this country on the IATA website.

You can also find information about your passenger rights on our portal for citizens.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



Internal Restrictions:
*Public spaces and services: Information on nationwide restrictions related to coronavirus is available on the Estonian crisis website. You should read the full list of nationwide restrictions. Estonia will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. If you are travelling with a printed PDF proof of vaccination status, it must date from 1 November to ensure that the certificate can be scanned successfully, if domestic certification is required. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
* Travel via neighbouring countries: Check country-specific for details on travel restrictions in the neighbouring countries Finland, Latvia, Lithuania and Russia.
* If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
